docs.snippet: SAY bisque and immediately, unconscionable quantities of cream and mellowing chunks of lobster or some mushrooms comes to mind. But to be creamy, a bisque does not require cream.     A smooth vegetable purée, often involving a starchy root, can b...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAY bisque and immediately, unconscionable quantities of cream and mellowing chunks of lobster or some mushrooms comes to mind. But to be creamy, a bisque does not require cream. A smooth vegetable purée, often involving a starchy root, can be made with low-fat milk yet deliver a rich creaminess nonetheless. Here are a trio of them for winter dinners.

headline.main: Trio of Bisques That Can Be Creamy Without Cream

docs.snippet: BRINING works wonders with ham or turkey, producing juicy, firm meat. When I read recently that the method works well for pork, too I was intrigued. Pork has so little fat that it often comes out dry and tough when it's cooked.     So I tried brin...
docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson Food column describes how to brine pork chops; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: BRINING works wonders with ham or turkey, producing juicy, firm meat. When I read recently that the method works well for pork, too I was intrigued. Pork has so little fat that it often comes out dry and tough when it's cooked. So I tried brining some chops overnight, using apple cider on one occasion, and on another in a mixure of cranberry and apple juices. It worked. The meat was so tender it was almost buttery, but it wasn't salty.

headline.main: Brining Pork Chops Makes for Tenderness

docs.snippet: THE calendar may say autumn, but summer lingers at produce stands. There's still time to enjoy fresh sweet corn and ripe tomatoes. And with them, the pungent seasoning provided by fresh cilantro is always welcome.    Each of the following recipes ...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE calendar may say autumn, but summer lingers at produce stands. There's still time to enjoy fresh sweet corn and ripe tomatoes. And with them, the pungent seasoning provided by fresh cilantro is always welcome. Each of the following recipes calls for corn kernels stripped from the cob, along with cilantro and ripe tomatoes. Once the local season is finished for these treasures, the recipes can still be made using kernels stripped from corn that has come from the South and ripe plum tomatoes from California, which are often available until winter.

headline.main: End-of-the-Season Dishes Made Easy With Corn and Tomatoes

docs.snippet: HAVE bluefish fallen by the wayside? Are shoppers passing it by in favor of fancier and costlier varieties like tuna, salmon and red snapper?     If so, it's a pity. Bluefish is a local catch, readily available in summer. The fish is full of flavo...
docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant Food column offers recipes for fillet of bluefish (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: HAVE bluefish fallen by the wayside? Are shoppers passing it by in favor of fancier and costlier varieties like tuna, salmon and red snapper? If so, it's a pity. Bluefish is a local catch, readily available in summer. The fish is full of flavor, but it has drawbacks. Some people complain that it is a strong-tasting fish, a condition that tends to occur mainly when bluefish is not perfectly fresh. Its natural oiliness means that it is rich in healthy omega-3 and that it will have a rich meatiness when cooked.

headline.main: Three Ways to Use Fillets of Bluefish

docs.snippet: POTATO salad may not strictly be seasonal, but like local strawberries, backyard grilling and gin and tonic, it signals summer. And its adaptable nature makes it appropriate for everything from a picnic to an elaborate dinner.    Defining potato s...
docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant Food column offers variety of potato salad recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: POTATO salad may not strictly be seasonal, but like local strawberries, backyard grilling and gin and tonic, it signals summer. And its adaptable nature makes it appropriate for everything from a picnic to an elaborate dinner. Defining potato salad is cultural. Whether or not the recipe calls for a mayonnaise dressing, warm bacon, hard-cooked eggs, chunks of unpeeled potatoes, a sharp vinegar edge, grated carrot, a touch of sweetness or diced herring, often depends on the heritage of the cook. Potato salad can involve any of these variations, and more.

headline.main: Potato Salad Always Welcome, Indoors and Out

docs.snippet: ONE spring a few years ago I stopped at a farm with my son, who was then about 5, to buy some seedlings. Behind the barn was an enormous field full of young spinach, and we were told we could pick our own. When we got home I showed him how to make...
docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson Food column offers recipes for spinash salads and spinach soup; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: ONE spring a few years ago I stopped at a farm with my son, who was then about 5, to buy some seedlings. Behind the barn was an enormous field full of young spinach, and we were told we could pick our own. When we got home I showed him how to make a dressing I knew he would like because it contained soy sauce. It was my sneaky way of getting him to eat spinach, and since then we've had this salad many times. Despite the fact that most children won't have it in the house, spinach is the most widely grown green vegetable in the United States, at its best in spring and fall, when the temperature is cool. It should be bright and squeaky, the leaves dark green, not yellow or withered. Small tender leaves are good for salads, the thicker ones for cooking.

headline.main: Spinach: From Simply Salad to Soup

docs.snippet: PERHAPS it is all the Easter egg painting kits around, but come spring, I feel like doing more with eggs than just serving them for breakfast. ''Country Egg, City Egg,'' just published by Artisan, is a charming little book by Gayle Pirie and John ...
docs.abstract: in serving eggs, breakfast isn't the only option**Food column offers egg recipes for meals other than breakfast (S)''''''
docs.lead_paragraph: PERHAPS it is all the Easter egg painting kits around, but come spring, I feel like doing more with eggs than just serving them for breakfast. ''Country Egg, City Egg,'' just published by Artisan, is a charming little book by Gayle Pirie and John Clark, former chefs at Zuni Cafe in San Francisco, with many ideas for egg dishes. One is made with chorizo, a spicy Mexican pork sausage seasoned with dried ancho and pasilla chilies, cinnamon, clove and vinegar. The sausage is sauteed until crisp and folded with sauteed onions into the eggs as they are softly scrambled. The eggs are served on a warm tortilla. In spring, I also like to make frittata, an Italian open-faced omelette, with tender young asparagus spears. I saute them with prosciutto (you can leave this out for a vegetarian dish) and mix with the eggs, which are sprinkled with Parmesan and cooked under the broiler until puffy and golden.

headline.main: In Serving Eggs, Breakfast Isn't The Only Option

docs.snippet: SUPPOSE you decide to follow tradition and prepare corned beef and cabbage for St. Patrick's Day. And suppose you are then faced with an ample supply of leftover corned beef. Sandwiches would be one obvious option. Hash is another.    Corned beef ...
docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant on preparation of hash with leftover corned beef; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: SUPPOSE you decide to follow tradition and prepare corned beef and cabbage for St. Patrick's Day. And suppose you are then faced with an ample supply of leftover corned beef. Sandwiches would be one obvious option. Hash is another. Corned beef may be the best-known and most popular hash ingredient, but it is not the only basis for hash. Starting with dicings of potatoes and onions, other options include seafood, chicken and mushrooms. The term hash comes from the French ''hacher,'' which means to chop.

headline.main: Suggestions for Making Hash With Leftover Corned Beef

docs.snippet: IT is time to get back to basics. Hearty cold-weather dishes can now replace the elegant tidbits or rarefied luxuries that dressed up dining over the last few celebratory weeks.     For millennia, long before the last one, dried beans have been a ...
docs.abstract: Food column offers recipes using beans (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: IT is time to get back to basics. Hearty cold-weather dishes can now replace the elegant tidbits or rarefied luxuries that dressed up dining over the last few celebratory weeks. For millennia, long before the last one, dried beans have been a cold-weather staple to nourish people the world over. Here are three recipes that suit the season. One is a sturdy soup, another a variation on macaroni and cheese, and the third is a meat and bean sauce for pasta.

headline.main: Dried Beans Provide Hearty Cold-Weather Dishes
